column2: CHAPTER III
column3: CHAPTER three

column2: Iuka, the fiercest battle of the war, 217 men out of 482 of my regiment are shot--The awful Rebel charge at Corinth--Moonlight on the battlefield--Bushels of arms and legs--Tombstones for fireplaces--One of Grant's mistakes.
column3: Iuka, the fiercest battle of the war, two hundred seventeen men out of four hundred eighty two of my regiment are shot-The awful Rebel charge at Corinth-Moonlight on the battlefield-Bushels of arms and legs-Tombstones for fireplaces-One of Grant's mistakes.

column2: All that summer, after taking Corinth, we chased up and down the State of Mississippi, trying to get fair battle with the Rebel army.
column3: All that summer, after taking Corinth, we chased up and down the State of Mississippi, trying to get fair battle with the Rebel army.

column2: At last the chance came, and for my regiment it was an awful one--the battle of Iuka.
column3: At last the chance came, and for my regiment it was an awful one-the battle of Iuka.

column2: The battle of Iuka took place on the 19th of September, 1862.
column3: The battle of Iuka took place on the nineteenth of September, eighteen sixty two.

column2: It was fought by a handful of the troops of General Rosecrans against half the army of General Price.
column3: It was fought by a handful of the troops of General Rosecrans against half the army of General Price.

column2: Grant was only a few miles away, but although commander-in-chief, he knew nothing of the hardest-fought battle of the Civil War until it was over.
column3: Grant was only a few miles away, but although commander in chief, he knew nothing of the hardest fought battle of the Civil War until it was over.

column2: One morning before daylight while camped in the woods near Jacinto half expecting to be attacked, we heard that Price's army was in Iuka, some eighteen miles away, and that if we would hurry there and attack from one side, General Grant, with Ord's troops, would attack from another side.
column3: One morning before daylight while camped in the woods near Jacinto half expecting to be attacked, we heard that Price's army was in Iuka, some eighteen miles away, and that if we would hurry there and attack from one side, General Grant, with Ord's troops, would attack from another side.

column2: How eagerly the regiment made the forward march on that beautiful autumn day!
column3: How eagerly the regiment made the forward march on that beautiful autumn day!

column2: The woods were in their fairest foliage, and it seemed too lovely a day for war and bloodshed.
column3: The woods were in their fairest foliage, and it seemed too lovely a day for war and bloodshed.

column2: The bugles played occasionally as the men hurried along, but not a shot was fired.
column3: The bugles played occasionally as the men hurried along, but not a shot was fired.

column2: No noise like war fell on the soldiers' ears as they tramped over the beautiful country road toward the Tennessee River.
column3: No noise like war fell on the soldiers' ears as they tramped over the beautiful country road toward the Tennessee River.

column2: They had time for reflection as they marched, and they knew now they were going to battle.
column3: They had time for reflection as they marched, and they knew now they were going to battle.

column2: There had been no time for letters or farewells, and each thought the other one, not himself, most likely to fall in the coming engagement.
column3: There had been no time for letters or farewells, and each thought the other one, not himself, most likely to fall in the coming engagement.

column2: There were only 482 of my little regiment now marching there, hoping, almost praying, the enemy might only wait.
column3: There were only four hundred eighty two of my little regiment now marching there, hoping, almost praying, the enemy might only wait.

column2: How little anyone dreamed that before the sun set 217 of that little command would be stretched dead or dying among the autumn leaves!
column3: How little anyone dreamed that before the sun set two hundred seventeen of that little command would be stretched dead or dying among the autumn leaves!

column2: It was just two o'clock when the regiment ran on to the army of the enemy, lying in line right across the road close to Iuka.
column3: It was just two o'clock when the regiment ran on to the army of the enemy, lying in line right across the road close to Iuka.

column2: My own regiment was in the advance.
column3: My own regiment was in the advance.

column2: Instantly it, too, was in line of battle across that road, and in a few minutes absolutely the fiercest little conflict of the war began.
column3: Instantly it, too, was in line of battle across that road, and in a few minutes absolutely the fiercest little conflict of the war began.

column2: Our brigade was fearfully outnumbered. Rosecrans, had ten thousand soldiers within five miles of the battlefield, yet let three or four small regiments and a battery do all the fighting.
column3: Our brigade was fearfully outnumbered. Rosecrans, had ten thousand soldiers within five miles of the battlefield, yet let three or four small regiments and a battery do all the fighting.

column2: Ten miles away, in another direction, lay General Grant and General Ord, with many other thousands, as silent as if paralyzed. An unlucky wind blew, they said, and the sound of our cannon, that was to have been the signal for them to attack also, was unheard by them.
column3: Ten miles away, in another direction, lay General Grant and General Ord, with many other thousands, as silent as if paralyzed. An unlucky wind blew, they said, and the sound of our cannon, that was to have been the signal for them to attack also, was unheard by them.

column2: Charge after charge was made upon our little line, and the Eleventh Ohio Battery, which the regiment was protecting, was taken and retaken three times.
column3: Charge after charge was made upon our little line, and the Eleventh Ohio Battery, which the regiment was protecting, was taken and retaken three times.

column2: There were no breastworks, yet that one little brigade of Hamilton's division stood there in the open and repulsed assault after assault.
column3: There were no breastworks, yet that one little brigade of Hamilton's division stood there in the open and repulsed assault after assault.

column2: It was the Iowa, the Missouri, and the Ohio boys against the boys of Alabama and Mississippi, and the grass and leaves were covered with the bodies in blue and gray.
column3: It was the Iowa, the Missouri, and the Ohio boys against the boys of Alabama and Mississippi, and the grass and leaves were covered with the bodies in blue and gray.

column2: Not Balaklava, nor the Alma, saw such fighting.
column3: Not Balaklava, nor the Alma, saw such fighting.

column2: It was a duel to the death.
column3: It was a duel to the death.

column2: For hours the blue and the gray stood within forty yards of each other and poured in sheets of musketry. Every horse of the battery at the left of my regiment was killed, and every gunner but one or two was shot and lying among the debris.
column3: For hours the blue and the gray stood within forty yards of each other and poured in sheets of musketry. Every horse of the battery at the left of my regiment was killed, and every gunner but one or two was shot and lying among the debris.

column2: No battery in the whole four years' war lost so many men in so short a time.
column3: No battery in the whole four years' war lost so many men in so short a time.

column2: Antietam, Gettysburg, the Wilderness, could show nothing like it. Only the setting sun put an end to what was part of the time a hand to hand conflict.
column3: Antietam, Gettysburg, the Wilderness, could show nothing like it. Only the setting sun put an end to what was part of the time a hand to hand conflict.

column2: One daring Rebel was shot down and bayoneted clear behind the line of Company B, where he had broken through to seize the flag of my regiment.
column3: One daring Rebel was shot down and bayoneted clear behind the line of Company B, where he had broken through to seize the flag of my regiment.

column2: That night the enemy slipped away, leaving hundreds and hundreds of his dead and wounded on the field.
column3: That night the enemy slipped away, leaving hundreds and hundreds of his dead and wounded on the field.

column2: With a few lanterns our men then went about and tried to gather up the wounded; the dead were left till morning.
column3: With a few lanterns our men then went about and tried to gather up the wounded; the dead were left till morning.

column2: There were 782 Union men lying there in their blood that long night, 608 of them out of a single small brigade.
column3: There were seven hundred eighty two Union men lying there in their blood that long night, six hundred eight of them out of a single small brigade.

column2: While mothers and sisters at home were praying for the safety of these dear ones at the front, their spirits that night were leaving their torn bodies in the dark and ascending heavenward.
column3: While mothers and sisters at home were praying for the safety of these dear ones at the front, their spirits that night were leaving their torn bodies in the dark and ascending heavenward.

column2: Five of my eight messmates of the day before were shot.
column3: Five of my eight messmates of the day before were shot.

column2: It was not a question who was dead, or wounded, but who was _not_.
column3: It was not a question who was dead, or wounded, but who was underscore not underscore.

column2: Fifteen officers of our little half regiment were dead or wounded.
column3: Fifteen officers of our little half regiment were dead or wounded.

column2: The enemy lost more than one thousand men in trying to destroy that single brigade and its Ohio battery.
column3: The enemy lost more than one thousand men in trying to destroy that single brigade and its Ohio battery.

column2: The burying party the next morning found nineteen dead Rebels lying together at one place.
column3: The burying party the next morning found nineteen dead Rebels lying together at one place.

column2: At another spot 182 Rebel corpses lay in a row covered by tarpaulins.
column3: At another spot one hundred eighty two Rebel corpses lay in a row covered by tarpaulins.

column2: The enemy had not had time to bury them.
column3: The enemy had not had time to bury them.

column2: It was a principle among our generals that if a command fought well in a battle or got cut all to pieces, that was the particular command to be put at the very front in the next hard scrap.
column3: It was a principle among our generals that if a command fought well in a battle or got cut all to pieces, that was the particular command to be put at the very front in the next hard scrap.

column2: And so it was that within two weeks my regiment was placed outside the breastworks at Corinth, to wait and receive another awful assault.
column3: And so it was that within two weeks my regiment was placed outside the breastworks at Corinth, to wait and receive another awful assault.

column2: The night before the battle of Corinth the Fifth Iowa Regiment lay across the Purdy road, in the bright moonlight.
column3: The night before the battle of Corinth the Fifth Iowa Regiment lay across the Purdy road, in the bright moonlight.

column2: I remained awake all night, talking with a comrade who shared my blanket with me.
column3: I remained awake all night, talking with a comrade who shared my blanket with me.

column2: Poor Jimmy King! he survived the war only to be murdered later on a plantation in Mississippi.
column3: Poor Jimmy King! he survived the war only to be murdered later on a plantation in Mississippi.

column2: As we lay there in the wagon road, the awful losses of my regiment at Iuka kept us thinking there in the moonlight what would happen on the morrow.
column3: As we lay there in the wagon road, the awful losses of my regiment at Iuka kept us thinking there in the moonlight what would happen on the morrow.

column2: When morning came the firing opened, and for all that day the battle raged fiercely at the left and center left, we getting the worst of it, too.
column3: When morning came the firing opened, and for all that day the battle raged fiercely at the left and center left, we getting the worst of it, too.

column2: The Rebels were charging works that they themselves had built when they held the town during Halleck's siege. General Haccelman and many other of our officers had fallen.
column3: The Rebels were charging works that they themselves had built when they held the town during Halleck's siege. General Haccelman and many other of our officers had fallen.

column2: Our own division, though fighting some, had lost but few men.
column3: Our own division, though fighting some, had lost but few men.

column2: That evening an order came for us--Hamilton's Division--to assault the enemy's left flank at midnight.
column3: That evening an order came for us-Hamilton's Division-to assault the enemy's left flank at midnight.

column2: Before the hour came, however, the move was decided to be too dangerous, and we changed our position to one nearer the forts.
column3: Before the hour came, however, the move was decided to be too dangerous, and we changed our position to one nearer the forts.

column2: All the night we lay there under the brightest moonlight I ever saw.
column3: All the night we lay there under the brightest moonlight I ever saw.

column2: Under the same quiet moonlight, and only six hundred yards away from us, also lay the victorious Rebel army.
column3: Under the same quiet moonlight, and only six hundred yards away from us, also lay the victorious Rebel army.

column2: They believed Corinth as good as taken, but they had only captured our outer lines of forts.
column3: They believed Corinth as good as taken, but they had only captured our outer lines of forts.

column2: Yet it looked very bad for us.
column3: Yet it looked very bad for us.

column2: Every house in town was full of our wounded and our dead lay everywhere.
column3: Every house in town was full of our wounded and our dead lay everywhere.

column2: Once in the night I slipped away from the bivouac and hurried to the old Tishimingo Hotel, to see a lieutenant of my company, who had been shot through the breast.
column3: Once in the night I slipped away from the bivouac and hurried to the old Tishimingo Hotel, to see a lieutenant of my company, who had been shot through the breast.

column2: Never will I forget the horrible scenes of that night.
column3: Never will I forget the horrible scenes of that night.

column2: The town seemed full of the groans of dying men.
column3: The town seemed full of the groans of dying men.

column2: In one large room of the Tishimingo House surgeons worked all the night, cutting off arms and legs.
column3: In one large room of the Tishimingo House surgeons worked all the night, cutting off arms and legs.

column2: I could not help my friend.
column3: I could not help my friend.

column2: It was too late, for he was dying.
column3: It was too late, for he was dying.

column2: Go back to the regiment, he said, smiling, "all will be needed."
column3: Go back to the regiment, he said, smiling, "all will be needed."

column2: It was a relief to me to get back into the moonlight and out of the horror, yet out there lay thousands of others in line, only waiting the daylight to be also mangled and torn like these.
column3: It was a relief to me to get back into the moonlight and out of the horror, yet out there lay thousands of others in line, only waiting the daylight to be also mangled and torn like these.

column2: The moon shone so brightly the men in the lines, tired though they were, could scarcely sleep.
column3: The moon shone so brightly the men in the lines, tired though they were, could scarcely sleep.

column2: There the thousands lay, the blue and the gray, under the same peaceful moon, worshiping the same God, and each praying for dear ones North and South they would never again see.
column3: There the thousands lay, the blue and the gray, under the same peaceful moon, worshiping the same God, and each praying for dear ones North and South they would never again see.

column2: God could not answer the prayers of the men in both armies that night.
column3: God could not answer the prayers of the men in both armies that night.

column2: Had He done so, all would have been killed on the morrow.
column3: Had He done so, all would have been killed on the morrow.

column2: At early daybreak I again went to see my lieutenant.
column3: At early daybreak I again went to see my lieutenant.

column2: As I entered the building a cannonball from the enemy crashed through the house and killed four soldiers by the stairway.
column3: As I entered the building a cannonball from the enemy crashed through the house and killed four soldiers by the stairway.

column2: My friend, with many others, was being carried out to die elsewhere.
column3: My friend, with many others, was being carried out to die elsewhere.

column2: It was soon full day.
column3: It was soon full day.

column2: In one of the rooms I saw the floors, tables, and chairs covered with amputated limbs, some white and some broken and bleeding.
column3: In one of the rooms I saw the floors, tables, and chairs covered with amputated limbs, some white and some broken and bleeding.

column2: There were simply bushels of them, and the floor was running blood.
column3: There were simply bushels of them, and the floor was running blood.

column2: It was a strange, horrible sight,--but it was war.
column3: It was a strange, horrible sight,--but it was war.

column2: Yes, it was "hell." I hastened back to the lines.
column3: Yes, it was "hell." I hastened back to the lines.

column2: Nine o'clock came, and now we knew that the great assault was to be made.
column3: Nine o'clock came, and now we knew that the great assault was to be made.

column2: We looked for it against our own division, as we lay in the grass waiting.
column3: We looked for it against our own division, as we lay in the grass waiting.

column2: Suddenly we heard something, almost like a distant whirlwind.
column3: Suddenly we heard something, almost like a distant whirlwind.

column2: My regiment rose to its feet, fired a few moments at scattering Rebels in our front, and were amazed to see a great black column, ten thousand strong, moving like a mighty storm-cloud out of the woods and attacking the forts and troops at our left.
column3: My regiment rose to its feet, fired a few moments at scattering Rebels in our front, and were amazed to see a great black column, ten thousand strong, moving like a mighty storm cloud out of the woods and attacking the forts and troops at our left.

column2: Instantly we changed direction a little and, without further firing, witnessed one of the greatest assaults of any war.
column3: Instantly we changed direction a little and, without further firing, witnessed one of the greatest assaults of any war.

column2: It was the storming of Fort Robinett.
column3: It was the storming of Fort Robinett.

column2: The cloud of Rebels we had seen divided itself into three columns.
column3: The cloud of Rebels we had seen divided itself into three columns.

column2: These recklessly advanced on the forts, climbing over the fallen trees and bending their heads against the awful storm of grape and canister from all our cannon.
column3: These recklessly advanced on the forts, climbing over the fallen trees and bending their heads against the awful storm of grape and canister from all our cannon.

column2: A perfect blaze of close range musketry, too, mowed them down like grass.
column3: A perfect blaze of close range musketry, too, mowed them down like grass.

column2: Even a foe could feel pity to see brave men so cruelly slaughtered.
column3: Even a foe could feel pity to see brave men so cruelly slaughtered.

column2: When the assault had failed and the noise of battle was stilled, I hurried down in front of Robinett.
column3: When the assault had failed and the noise of battle was stilled, I hurried down in front of Robinett.

column2: My canteen was full of water and I pressed it to the lips of many a dying enemy--enemy no longer.
column3: My canteen was full of water and I pressed it to the lips of many a dying enemy-enemy no longer.

column2: Our grape shot had torn whole companies of men to pieces.
column3: Our grape shot had torn whole companies of men to pieces.

column2: They lay in heaps of dozens, even close up to the works.
column3: They lay in heaps of dozens, even close up to the works.

column2: General Rogers, who had led a brigade into the hopeless pit, lay on his back, dead, with his flag in his hand.
column3: General Rogers, who had led a brigade into the hopeless pit, lay on his back, dead, with his flag in his hand.

column2: _He was the fifth one to die carrying that flag._ When I reached him some cruel one had stripped him of his boots.
column3: underscore He was the fifth one to die carrying that flag.underscore When I reached him some cruel one had stripped him of his boots.

column2: Another had taken his fine gold watch.
column3: Another had taken his fine gold watch.

column2: In this attack on Corinth the brave Southerners lost 5000 wounded, and we buried 1423 of their dead on the battlefield.
column3: In this attack on Corinth the brave Southerners lost five thousand wounded, and we buried fourteen twenty three of their dead on the battlefield.

column2: Our own loss had been 2200 dead and wounded.
column3: Our own loss had been two thousand two hundred dead and wounded.

column2: That night I stood guard under an oak tree on the battlefield among the unburied dead.
column3: That night I stood guard under an oak tree on the battlefield among the unburied dead.

column2: Many of the wounded, even, had not yet been gathered up.
column3: Many of the wounded, even, had not yet been gathered up.

column2: The moon shone as brightly as the night before, while thousands who had lain there under its peaceful rays before the battle were now again sleeping, but never to waken.
column3: The moon shone as brightly as the night before, while thousands who had lain there under its peaceful rays before the battle were now again sleeping, but never to waken.

column2: Our regiment now pursued the flying Rebels with great vigor.
column3: Our regiment now pursued the flying Rebels with great vigor.

column2: The quantities of broken batteries, wagons, tents, knapsacks, guns, etc., strewn along the roads behind them were immense.
column3: The quantities of broken batteries, wagons, tents, knapsacks, guns, etc, strewn along the roads behind them were immense.

column2: At the Hatchie River the Rebels were momentarily headed off by a division under Hurlbut that had hurried across from Bolivar.
column3: At the Hatchie River the Rebels were momentarily headed off by a division under Hurlbut that had hurried across from Bolivar.

column2: A seven hours' battle was fought at the bridge, but the Rebels got away in another direction.
column3: A seven hours' battle was fought at the bridge, but the Rebels got away in another direction.

column2: Possibly the best friend I had in the world, save my kin, was killed at that bridge.
column3: Possibly the best friend I had in the world, save my kin, was killed at that bridge.

column2: It was Lieutenant William Dodd, a classmate in school.
column3: It was Lieutenant William Dodd, a classmate in school.

column2: His head was shot off by a cannonball just as his regiment was charging at the bridge.
column3: His head was shot off by a cannonball just as his regiment was charging at the bridge.

column2: The pursuit of the enemy was being pushed with vigor when the army was ordered to desist and return to camp.
column3: The pursuit of the enemy was being pushed with vigor when the army was ordered to desist and return to camp.

column2: It was an astounding order, as it was in our power to destroy the defeated and flying columns.
column3: It was an astounding order, as it was in our power to destroy the defeated and flying columns.

column2: That order was one of the mistakes of Grant's earlier days as a commander.
column3: That order was one of the mistakes of Grant's earlier days as a commander.

column2: Indeed, we of the rank and file had little confidence in Grant in those days.
column3: Indeed, we of the rank and file had little confidence in Grant in those days.

column2: We reflected that at Shiloh he was miles away from the battlefield at the critical moment.
column3: We reflected that at Shiloh he was miles away from the battlefield at the critical moment.

column2: Sherman had saved the Union army from destruction there.
column3: Sherman had saved the Union army from destruction there.

column2: At Iuka, Grant, though commander, did not even know a battle was going on.
column3: At Iuka, Grant, though commander, did not even know a battle was going on.

column2: At Corinth he was forty miles away, and now, when we had the enemy almost within our grasp, he suddenly called us back.
column3: At Corinth he was forty miles away, and now, when we had the enemy almost within our grasp, he suddenly called us back.

column2: Rosecrans protested.
column3: Rosecrans protested.

column2: It was in vain.
column3: It was in vain.

column2: The order, more imperative than before, was repeated.
column3: The order, more imperative than before, was repeated.

column2: It required months, and great events, to make Grant the hero of the army which he afterward became.
column3: It required months, and great events, to make Grant the hero of the army which he afterward became.

column2: This entry I find in my diary in one of those days: "Our commander of the district is General U. S. Grant, who took Donelson; but aside from that one hour's fighting, and a little fighting at Shiloh, the troops know little about him.
column3: This entry I find in my diary in one of those days: "Our commander of the district is General u s Grant, who took Donelson; but aside from that one hour's fighting, and a little fighting at Shiloh, the troops know little about him.

column2: Rosecrans is at present the hero of this army, and, with him leading it, the boys would storm Hades."
column3: Rosecrans is at present the hero of this army, and, with him leading it, the boys would storm Hades."

column2: With the mercury at one hundred, the dust in the roads ankle deep, and the whole atmosphere yellow and full of it, the regiments exhausted by the pursuit, and yet disgusted at our recall, slowly tramped their way back to Corinth.
column3: With the mercury at one hundred, the dust in the roads ankle deep, and the whole atmosphere yellow and full of it, the regiments exhausted by the pursuit, and yet disgusted at our recall, slowly tramped their way back to Corinth.

column2: Now I visited my wounded companions in the hospital.
column3: Now I visited my wounded companions in the hospital.

column2: On inquiry for certain ones I learned that they were dead and lying out in the improvised graveyard near by.
column3: On inquiry for certain ones I learned that they were dead and lying out in the improvised graveyard near by.

column2: For some reason the dead at Hatchie Bridge were not buried.
column3: For some reason the dead at Hatchie Bridge were not buried.

column2: A week after the battle my brother rode by there on a cavalry expedition and made the horrible discovery that hogs were eating up the bodies of our dead heroes.
column3: A week after the battle my brother rode by there on a cavalry expedition and made the horrible discovery that hogs were eating up the bodies of our dead heroes.

column2: _That too was war._
column3: underscore That too was war.underscore

column2: We now camped on the edge of the town and went on building still other and greater forts.
column3: We now camped on the edge of the town and went on building still other and greater forts.

column2: Many of the soldiers made huts for themselves.
column3: Many of the soldiers made huts for themselves.

column2: It was getting cooler now, and little fireplaces were built in the huts and tents.
column3: It was getting cooler now, and little fireplaces were built in the huts and tents.

column2: Brick was scarce, and in a few instances the men used the stone slabs from a graveyard close at hand.
column3: Brick was scarce, and in a few instances the men used the stone slabs from a graveyard close at hand.

column2: It seemed vandalism, but the dead did not need them and the living did.
column3: It seemed vandalism, but the dead did not need them and the living did.
